The State Administrator shall establish a Problem Resolution Office with officers authorized to investigate taxpayer complaints and stop collection activities if deemed non-compliant with the law. Reversal of the injunction can only be done by the highest official or General Counsel with clear evidence, and officers cannot be penalized for their actions. The authority to reverse administrative injunctions cannot be delegated without clear evidence. Problem Resolution Officers cannot be disciplined unless a pattern of issuing unreasonable injunctions is proven. State Administrators and taxpayers retain the right to pursue legal remedies in court. SEC. 53. JURISDICTION AND INTERSTATE ALLOCATION. The text discusses the allocation of revenue between states based on the destination of taxable property or services. A Federal Office of Revenue Allocation will be established to resolve disputes among states regarding revenue allocation. The Administrator of the Office of Revenue Allocation determines revenue allocation between states based on the destination of tangible personal property. Judicial review is available with a standard of abuse of discretion. The destination of tangible personal property is determined by the Administrator of the Office of Revenue Allocation. Real property is allocated based on the location of the property, while other property is based on the purchaser's residence. Services are allocated based on where they are used, consumed, or enjoyed. The destination of services is determined by the state or territory where they are used, consumed, or enjoyed. Telecommunications services are allocated based on the purchaser's residence, while domestic transportation services are based on the final destinations within the United States. For services within the United States, the destination is the final destination of the trip. For international services, 50% of the service amount is attributed to the United States. Financial intermediation services are determined by the residence of the recipient. Financial intermediation services are determined by the residence of the recipient. State Tax Administrators have jurisdiction over gross payments with a destination within their state. Rents and royalties for tangible property are attributed to where the property is located. The destination of rents and royalties for tangible property is where the property is located. For vehicles, rent and lease payments are based on the location where the vehicle was delivered for short-term leases and the residence of the lessee for long-term leases. The tax must be stated and charged separately according to Section 54. The sales tax for taxable property or services must be charged separately by the vendor, and a receipt provided to the purchaser with details including the price exclusive of tax, amount of tax paid, price inclusive of tax, and the tax rate. The requirements for sales tax include the property or service price inclusive of tax, tax rate, sale date, vendor name, and vendor registration number. Vending machines are exempt from these requirements. Vending machines must dispense taxable property in exchange for coins or bills up to twenty dollars, and cannot sell items exceeding ten dollars each. The State Administrator or Secretary can enter installment agreements with taxpayers to pay taxes in installments, and compromise on amounts due. SEC. 56. ACCOUNTING. Vendors and persons must remit taxes based on when payment is received. An election can be made to use the accrual method for reporting transactions. For bad debts under the accrual method, refer to section 11(g). SEC. 57. HOBBY ACTIVITIES. SEC. 57. HOBBY ACTIVITIES. The exemption for non-profit trade or business is not available for taxable property or services. If gross payments exceed certain criteria in 2 of the last 4 years, the business is deemed for profit. The Internal Revenue Service appropriations for expenses, including income tax processing, revenue accounting, and payroll tax data transfer, are not authorized. New subsections are added to Section 7801 for the Excise Tax Bureau and Sales Tax Bureau within the Department of Treasury. The Sales Tax Bureau is established in the Department of Treasury to administer the national sales tax and other related federal duties. The Secretary of the Treasury can appoint up to 5 Assistant General Counsels without following civil service laws. The Treasury can appoint up to 5 Assistant General Counsels without following civil service laws. For tax years ending June 30, 1999, the tax imposed by section 1 and section 11 will be modified. Dollar figures in section 1 and section 11 will be halved for calendar year taxpayers. For fiscal year taxpayers, the dollar figures in section 1 and section 11 will be adjusted based on the taxpayer's taxable year ending June 30, 1999. The Secretary will publish tax rate schedules accordingly. Starting January 1, 1999, the Social Security Administration will collect payroll taxes. This includes self-employment income taxes and employment taxes as per the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 7 of the Act covers revised rules for self-employment tax. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to define 'self-employment income' as gross payments received in a calendar year from the sale of taxable property or services, minus purchases of taxable property or services, wages paid for business purposes, unused transition amounts, and undeducted negative self-employment income from prior periods. The transition amounts for the ten calendar years starting in 1999 are calculated based on the unrecovered basis amount as of December 31, 1998, divided by ten. This amount pertains to prior law section 167 property placed in service before January 1, 1999, and inventory held at the end of 1998. Prior law section 167 property placed in service before January 1, 1999, and inventory held at the end of 1998 are included in the transition amounts. Subsections 1402(b) and 1402(c) are repealed, while subsections 1402(d) et seq. are renumbered as subsections 1402(b) et seq. SEC. 8. SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS INDEXED ON SALES TAX INCLUSIVE BASIS. The text chunk discusses the amendment of the Consumer Price Index increase percentage calculation for Social Security benefits under the Social Security Act. The text chunk explains the calculation of the CPI increase percentage for Social Security benefits under the Social Security Act, based on the most recent prior calendar quarter or cost-of-living computation quarter. The text chunk details the calculation of the CPI increase percentage for Social Security benefits under the Social Security Act, based on the most recent prior calendar quarter or cost-of-living computation quarter. It involves the Consumer Price Index, national sales tax factor, and sales tax rate. The 'tax factor' calculation involves the sales tax rate divided by one minus the sales tax rate. SEC. 9. COMPENSATING PAYMENTS TO CERTAIN PERSONS ON FIXED INCOME. Compensating Payment: Eligible persons receive a compensating payment if they comply with the application requirements. The payment is calculated based on the qualified fixed income payment amount and the excess inflation rate. An eligible person is someone who receives Social Security benefits and qualified fixed income payments. Qualified fixed income payments are defined as payments received by beneficiaries under a defined benefit plan or by annuitants under an annuity contract with an insurance company. These payments are received by individuals entitled to Social Security benefits. Payments under an annuity contract are not considered qualified fixed income payments if they fluctuate based on investment performance, interest rates, or inflation. Payments from annuity contracts entered into after June 30, 1999, are also not qualified fixed income payments. Additionally, payments from a defined benefit plan to a beneficiary who was a participant in the plan for less than 5 years are not considered qualified fixed income payments. The qualified fixed income payment amount is \1/12\ of qualified fixed income payments that an eligible person is entitled to receive during the calendar year subsequent to the year for which the compensating payment is calculated, provided that it does not exceed $5,000. The term "excess inflation rate" refers to the excess of the consumer price index. The excess inflation rate is defined as the difference between the consumer price index during a specific period and the projected increase in the index. To receive compensating payments, eligible individuals must submit an application in the prescribed form. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may require insurers to apply for compensating payments, which will be received with Social Security benefits and funded from the general fund. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may require insurers to issue statements to annuitants or plan participants for determining qualified fixed income payment amounts. SEC. 10 amends Section 6621 of the Internal Revenue Code by adjusting interest rates. SEC. 11 requires a supermajority to raise the rate. SEC. 11 requires a supermajority in the House of Representatives or the Senate to consider any bill that increases federal sales tax rates or reduces federal revenues. Waiver or suspension of this requirement requires a two-thirds affirmative vote.
